column2: MAINE PRACTICE PERMIT TEST
column4: Maine
column6: ME

column2: Question Text
column4: Answer1 Text
column6: Answer2 Text
column8: Answer3 Text

column2: 1. Defensive driving is a driving technique in which you as a driver:
column4: defend yourself against accidents by following close to the vehicle ahead.
column6: defend against accidents by driving your vehicle fast enough to stay ahead of traffic congestion.
column8: defend against poor drivers by getting ahead of them in traffic.
column10: identify dangerous driving situations and take action to avoid an accident.

column2: 2. A steady yellow light means:
column4: Be prepared to stop for the red light.
column6: Be prepared to go. The light will soon be green.
column8: Drive with caution.
column10: Stop, yield the right-of-way, and go.

column2: 3. Which of the following is a defensive driving skill/technique?
column4: Keep your vehicle in good condition.
column6: Maintain the correct speed.
column8: Do not drive if you are very weary.

column2: 4. This road sign means:
column4: A side road enters ahead
column6: Two one-way roads merge ahead
column8: All traffic must turn right

column2: 5. Which of the following does NOT affect the distance that it takes to stop your vehicle?
column4: Reaction distance.
column6: Braking distance.
column8: Perception time.

column2: 6. If a pedestrian is illegal crossing in the middle of the street (not at a crosswalk) you:
column4: do not have to stop for them.
column6: should increase your speed, honk your horn and proceed.
column8: must stop for them.

column2: 7. When you leave your vehicle unattended, you must:
column4: turn off the engine.
column6: lock the ignition and remove the ignition key.
column8: set the parking brake.

column2: 8. The best way to deal with tailgaters is to:
column4: pump your brakes to get them to back off.
column6: speed up to increase the space between you and the tailgater.
column8: ignore them completely.
column10: slow down to encourage the tailgater to pass.

column2: 9. To avoid having to make an emergency stop while driving in traffic, drivers should:
column4: drive in the right lane only.
column6: look ahead and maintain a safe following distance.
column8: sound their horn to warn other drivers.
column10: drive slower than the flow of traffic.

column2: 10. This road sign means:
column4: Right turn on red light permitted
column6: Stop Sign Ahead
column8: No Right Turn

column2: 11. This road sign means:
column4: Yield the right-of-way to oncoming vehicles
column6: You must make a complete stop
column8: Slow down or stop

column2: 12. This road sign means:
column4: Sharp left turn
column6: No U-turn
column8: U-turn permitted

column2: 13. What should you do if one of your tires blows out?
column4: Hold the steering wheel tight and slowly take your foot off the gas pedal.
column6: Hold the steering wheel tight and brake immediately to avoid the risk of skidding.
column8: Decrease speed, pull over to the right and sound your horn to warn the other vehicles.

column2: 14. Traffic signs and pavement markings must be:
column4: always obeyed.
column6: used as a guide only.
column8: followed only when other vehicles are present.
column10: followed only when a police officer is present.

column2: 15. Alcohol:
column4: increases reaction time.
column6: makes drivers more prone to take chances.
column8: makes it difficult for drivers to judge their condition.

column2: 16. If you hear a thumping sound while driving, you should:
column4: try your emergency lights.
column6: hook your shoe under the gas pedal and see if you can free it.
column8: pull the steering wheel back.
column10: get off the road and check your tires.

column2: 17. When changing lanes, you should remember that:
column4: vehicles with two outside mirrors have no blind spots.
column6: you should look over your left shoulder for a left lane change and your right shoulder for a right lane change.
column8: You only need to turn and look over your right shoulder for lane changes to the right or left.

column2: 18. When an aggressive driver confronts you, you should:
column4: Try to move away safely.
column6: Remain calm and relaxed.
column8: Report aggressive drivers to law enforcement authorities.

column2: 19. If a vehicle is approaching with high beams, drivers should look __________ until the vehicle passes.
column4: to the left of the road
column6: to the right of the road
column8: straight ahead
column10: at the center of the road

column2: 20. A diamond-shaped sign is a:
column4: school zone sign.
column6: speed limit sign.
column8: regulatory sign.

column2: 21. What should you do if you see smoke come from under the hood?
column4: Call the fire department and then pull off the road and park your vehicle.
column6: Try to fight the fire yourself.
column8: Jump off your car immediately, if it is safe to do so.
column10: Pull off the road and park your vehicle. Turn off the ignition, get away from the car and call the fire department.

column2: 22. When an approaching driver at night blinds you by failing to dim their high beams, you should look:
column4: towards the right side of the road.
column6: towards the left side of the road.
column8: straight down the middle of the road.
column10: None of the other answers is correct.

column2: 23. When entering an expressway from the entrance ramp, you should:
column4: cross over to the traffic lane as soon as possible.
column6: use the acceleration lane to blend into the traffic.
column8: go down to the bottom of the ramp and stop until it is safe to enter the expressway.

column2: 24. Emotions can affect your driving by:
column4: decreasing your chances of an accident.
column6: lessening your concentration on the driving task.
column8: making you more aware of others around you.
column10: causing you to go to sleep at the wheel.

column2: 25. Drivers must not drive at:
column4: a speed that is not prudent for the circumstances.
column6: a speed that is greater than reasonable.
column8: a speed that is greater than the posted speed limit.

column2: 26. You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
column4: honk your horn.
column6: stop to let pedestrians cross safely.
column8: claim your right-of-way and proceed with caution.
column10: speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.

column2: 27. The use of alcohol and/or drugs affects:
column4: alertness and judgement.
column6: concentration and reaction time.
column8: All of the above.

column2: 28. To avoid glare from headlights of an approaching car:
column4: flash your high beams.
column6: don't look directly into the oncoming headlights, look toward the right edge of your lane.
column8: stay focused on the center line on the road.

column2: 29. When driving in travel lanes on the roadway:
column4: you may stop to let out passengers.
column6: you may make back up quickly if there are no vehicles behind.
column8: do not stop for any reason, keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.
column10: you may make a U-turn if you get on the wrong entrance ramp of the freeway.

column2: 30. The shape and color of a route number sign indicate the type of roadway.
column4: False
column6: True

column2: 31. This sign means:
column4: U-turns are not allowed.
column6: No parking on pavement.
column8: Parking is not allowed.

column2: 32. When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:
column4: using the inside rearview mirror.
column6: checking the rearview and outside mirrors.
column8: using the outside rearview mirror.
column10: turning your head and glancing over your shoulder.

column2: 33. When driving at night, if an approaching car is using its high-beams you should:
column4: look toward the right edge of the road.
column6: turn your lights on and off.
column8: look toward the left edge of the road.

column2: 34. This sign means:
column4: Warning: a bikeway crosses the roadway ahead.
column6: Bicycle zone ahead.
column8: Bicycles should yield to vehicles ahead.
column10: The lane ahead is reserved for bicycles.

column2: 35. This road sign means:
column4: Church ahead
column6: Side road
column8: Do not enter

column2: 36. Which statement about drinking alcohol and driving is true?
column4: If you are under the legal BAC limit, your driving is not affected.
column6: After drinking, a cold shower will sober you up.
column8: Alcohol affects judgement and coordination, which are needed to drive safely.

column2: 37. To keep the driver behind you at a safe distance you should:
column4: drive 5 MPH faster than the car behind.
column6: keep a steady speed.
column8: drive 5 MPH slower than the car behind.

column2: 38. Drivers who are 21 years of age or older considered to be driving under the influence if their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is:
column4: .04 or more.
column6: .88 or more.
column8: .02 or more.

column2: 39. When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
column4: drive faster than the flow of traffic.
column6: drive slower than the flow of traffic.
column8: drive with the flow of traffic.

column2: 40. This road sign means:
column4: Left lane must turn right
column6: Divided highway starts
column8: Keep right

column2: 51. On a road with two or more lanes in the same direction, you approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its warning lights on. You must:
column4: pass the emergency vehicle as quickly as possible.
column6: slow down. If possible, change lanes.
column8: drive to the right side of the road and stop.
column10: maintain your current speed and stay in your lane.

column2: 52. To practice defensive driving you should:
column4: maintain a proper following distance.
column6: always leave yourself a way out.
column8: look well ahead of your vehicle and be aware of developing traffic situations around you.

column2: 53. When driving in foggy weather, drivers should:
column4: put their lights on high beam.
column6: put their emergency flashers on.
column8: put their lights on low beam.

column2: 54. Are drivers allowed to exceed the speed limit to pass other vehicles?
column4: Yes, but only by 10 MPH or less.
column6: Yes, except for school zones.
column8: No.
column10: Yes, but only if they drive with caution.

column2: 55. You are approaching an intersection with a yellow flashing light. You should:
column4: prepare to stop; the light is about to turn red.
column6: speed up to beat the red light.
column8: proceed with caution through the intersection.
column10: stop and wait for the light to change.

column2: 56. When you hear the warning signal or see the warning lamps of an emergency vehicle, you must:
column4: stop as quickly as you can.
column6: drive slowly until the emergency vehicle has passed.
column8: provide a clear path for the emergency vehicle and stop.

column2: 57. When on a short entrance to an interstate where there is no acceleration lane:
column4: enter the far right traffic lane and speed up to the flow of traffic.
column6: use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of the traffic.
column8: speed up on the entrance only after you have found a gap in traffic.

column2: 58. When you drive near parks and playgrounds, you should expect children:
column4: to know when it is safe to cross.
column6: to stop at the curb before crossing the street.
column8: not to cross unless they are with an adult.
column10: to suddenly run into the street.

column2: 59. A person walking with a white cane or guide dog is likely to be:
column4: a blind person.
column6: a deaf person.
column8: a traffic enforcement officer.

column2: 60. An aggressive driver:
column4: weaves in and out of traffic.
column6: competes with other traffic.
column8: shows little or no respect for traffic laws.
